text: (Iris speaking French)
(Fred speaking French)
(Iris speaking French)
(Alex speaking French)
(Fred speaking French)
(uplifting music)

- Paris is always
adapting, always changing.
Paris is thousands years old,

but today it's a central
space in the tech scene.
- I have a strong attachment to the city,
and I really want to build a company here,
even with international ambition.

But I'm convinced that
in France, in Paris,
you can create a unicorn.
I'm Iris Marechal,

I am the co-founder and
the CEO of Theremia.
At Theremia, we are building an AI-powered

precision medicine tool
for neurological diseases.
Currently, drugs are designed
with a one-size-fits-all approach,

without taking into account
differences in gender,
age, stage of the disease, or ethnicity.
We aim to really change the status quo
by creating better drugs for everyone.
So we are currently at Agoranov,
which is the oldest incubator in France.

What I love with the fact of
being surrounded by founders,
we all got the same issues.
So sharing your insights is actually

really, really efficient
and help us to be productive
and the best at what we're doing.
I think most entrepreneurs in France
are really driven by passion.

- There is something around
French culture about art.
We often say that code is poetry,
and I think that a lot of French people,

the relationship they
have with their code,
we can sometimes feel it.

There was always this
constant improvement,

constant way to challenge
myself, build better code,

have better naming
conventions, better syntax.
Hello, I'm Fred Petitpont,
I'm CTO and co-founder at Moments Lab.

At Moments Lab, our
mission is really to help

creative users, like
video editor, journalist,
producers, find the right moment they need

through petabytes of archive
in less than two seconds.
We had to choose technology and frameworks
that were proven on the market,
that had strong communities.
When it comes to GenAI,
AWS Bedrock is a very good way to go fast,

iterate fast, develop a new
feature in a matter of days,
and have it tested by customers.
And I think technology is moving so fast,
there is this curve that never stops,

but one thing that really helps
you being a better developer
is working with other talented people.

- [Olivier] And so gathering
as developers is very important

because we need to share ideas
and share how we do things
so we can learn from each other.
So today we're in Station F,
where we have the AWS GenAI Loft.

Station F was an incubator
that opened a few years ago.

It used to be a neighborhood
that was not very tech,
now we have a lot of startups coming here,
entrepreneurs living around,
communities, events happening here.

- It's very valuable to
have in-person experiences

because, otherwise, we are
just handles on GitHub.

And some conversations
that are a bit deeper,

getting to know people's
struggles, people's roadmaps,

it only can happen with these
sorts of in-person events.

I'm Alex. I'm one of the
co-founders of Giskard AI.
The name Giskard is a reference to,
in the books of Isaac Asimov,

the character of Giskard invents
the Zeroth Law of Robotics,

which says that robots
should not harm humanity.
And that's really our goal as a company

to make sure that actually
AI does not harm humanity.

And we embrace that mission
by providing testing tools.
The Paris AI scene

is different from the
scene in San Francisco
because we are underdogs,

but the will is the same of
building international companies
that have an impact.
So the ambition is there,

and within the next three
years, we have a lot to prove.
Having a developer community

is really important for
our generation of AI tools
because it's all about building trust.

I'm really hopeful for
seeing GenAI being used
in a lot more places.
I think we're still in the early days.

- [Olivier] And so it's
important that even people
from different industries gather together
to see how they're using GenAI.
- [Fred] There is a lot of openness.

People are eager to
learn more from others,
and there is really a way of life here,
a quality of life here that we do have
and that we're very proud to have.

- [Iris] French people
love the collaboration,
the communion, being together.

Learn more about your colleagues
in a more unofficial way.

And I really love that
about being a startup
in the French atmosphere.
(uplifting music)
(uplifting music ends)
